sen.j: 節刀（せっとう、せちとう）は、日本の古代（奈良時代から平安時代）において、天皇が出征する将軍または遣唐使の大使に持たせた、任命の印としての刀。
sen.e: Setto (or Sechito) refers to the sword which was granted by the Emperor to Shogun who was going to the front or Japanese mission to Tang Dynasty China as the sign of commission in ancient times of Japan (from the Nara period to the Heian period).

sen.j: 「節」は符節（割り符）のことで、使臣が印として持つ物の意。
sen.e: 'Setsu' means tally what an envoy had as a sign.

sen.j: 任務を終了すると、天皇に返還された。
sen.e: After their mission, the sword was returned to the Emperor.

sen.j: 節刀を持たされた将軍を持節将軍（じせつしょうぐん）、節刀を持たされた大使を持節大使（じせつたいし）という。
sen.e: Shogun who was granted Setto was called Jisetsu Shogun and an envoy who was granted Setto was called Jisetsu envoy.

sen.j: 持節将軍は、辺境の反乱を鎮定するために派遣される軍団の総指揮官で、鎮定する対象により、征隼人将軍、征夷大将軍、征東将軍などと呼ばれた。
sen.e: Jisetsu Shogun refers to a supreme commander of corps that were sent to a remote region to suppress the rebellion and the person was called Seihayato Taishogun, Seii Taishogun, Seito Shogun or etc. depending on what was suppressed.

sen.j: 『日本書紀』によれば、継体天皇21年（527年）に起きた磐井の乱に際して、筑紫君磐井の征討を命じられた物部麁鹿火に、継体天皇が刀を授けたことが、節刀の初めとされる。
sen.e: According to "Nihonshoki," Setto stemmed from that the Emperor Keitai granted the sword to MONONOBE no Arakahi who was assigned to conquer Tsukushinokimiiwai in the Iwai War occurred in 527.

sen.j: その後も、大宝元年（701年）に民部尚書と遣唐執節使に任じられた粟田真人に文武天皇が授けた例や、延暦20年（801年）に蝦夷討伐を命じられた征夷大将軍の坂上田村麻呂に桓武天皇が授けた例などがよく知られる。
sen.e: Also, there are well-known examples which the Emperor Monmu granted the sword to AWATA no Mahito who was appointed to Minbu Shosho and Shitsusetsushi (an envoy to Chaina) in 701 and the Emperor Kammu granted the sword to Seii Taishogun SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro who was assigned to conquer Ezo (Northerners) in 801.

sen.j: 将軍や大使に節刀を授ける習わしは、遣唐使が廃止され、辺境の反乱が減少した平安時代末期には廃れた。
sen.e: The custom which the emperor granted Setto to Shogun or an envoy became obsolete at the end of the Heian Period when Kentoushi (a Japanese mission to Tang Dynasty China) was abolished and rebellion in remote regions was reduced.

sen.e: At the end of the Edo Period over several centuries after that, Setto-kashi (Imperial grant) came to attention as a political ceremony.
